name: Almond Mushroom
description: A gilled mushroom with a sweet almond-like scent, often cultivated for medicinal properties.
habitat: Warm climates, grassy areas, compost-rich soil

name: Amanita gemmata
description: A yellowish cap covered with white warts, resembling a small Amanita muscaria.
habitat: Coniferous and mixed forests in Europe and North America

name: Amethyst Chanterelle
description: A vibrant purple chanterelle with a fruity aroma and funnel-shaped cap.
habitat: Deciduous forests, often near oak or beech trees

name: Amethyst Deceiver
description: A small, purple mushroom that fades with age, often found in mossy woodlands.
habitat: Damp forests, especially under deciduous trees

name: Aniseed Funnel
description: A pale blue-green mushroom with a strong aniseed scent.

name: Ascot Hat
description: A small, bell-shaped mushroom with a translucent cap, often found on decaying wood.
habitat: Decaying logs and stumps in coastal regions

name: Bay Bolete
description: A brown-capped bolete with a creamy pore surface that bruises blue.
habitat: Coniferous forests, often near pine trees

name: Bearded Milkcap
description: A pale, fuzzy-capped mushroom with white latex that turns pink when exposed.
habitat: Boreal forests, often near birch trees

name: Beechwood Sickener
description: A bright red-capped mushroom with brittle white gills.

name: Beefsteak Fungus
description: A reddish, tongue-like fungus that resembles raw meat and bleeds a red liquid when cut.
habitat: Oak trees, especially on wounds or stumps

name: Birch Polypore
description: A bracket fungus with a pale upper surface and white pores, commonly found on birch trees.

name: Birch Woodwart
description: A small, black, crust-like fungus that grows on decaying birch wood.

name: Bitter Beech Bolete
description: A striking bolete with a red stem and yellow pores that bruise blue.
habitat: Deciduous forests, especially under beech trees

name: Bitter Bolete
description: A brown-capped bolete with a pinkish pore surface and a bitter taste.

name: Black Bulgar
description: A black, gelatinous fungus that grows in clusters on dead oak wood.

name: Black Morel
description: A honeycombed, conical mushroom prized by foragers.

name: Blackening Brittlegill
description: A white mushroom that turns black with age or when damaged.

name: Blackening Polypore
description: A large, fan-shaped polypore that blackens when touched or aged.
habitat: Base of deciduous trees, especially beech

name: Blackening Waxcap
description: A brightly colored waxcap that turns black with age or handling.

name: Blue Roundhead
description: A blue-green mushroom with white gills and a sticky cap.
habitat: Grassy areas, wood chips, and disturbed soils

name: Blushing Bracket
description: A tough, woody bracket fungus with a reddish-brown surface and maze-like pores.
habitat: Dead hardwood trees, especially willow and birch

name: Blushing Rosette
description: A irregularly shaped polypore that exudes red droplets when young.
habitat: Stumps and logs of deciduous trees

name: Blushing Wood Mushroom
description: A woodland mushroom with a white cap that stains pink when bruised.
habitat: Coniferous forests, often near spruce or pine

name: Bovine Bolete
description: A slimy-capped bolete with yellow pores, often found near pine trees.

name: Bronze Bolete
description: A dark brown bolete with a velvety cap and pores that bruise blue-green.

name: Brown Birch Bolete
description: A brown-capped bolete with a scaly stem, commonly found under birch trees.

name: Brown Rollrim
description: A brown, funnel-shaped mushroom with inrolled margins; causes severe immune reactions.
habitat: Forests, often near birch or pine

name: Bruising Webcap
description: A purple-tinged mushroom that bruises dark blue when handled.

name: Butter Cap
description: A tiny, bright yellow mushroom with a gelatinous texture.

name: Cauliflower Fungus
description: A large, brain-like fungus with creamy-white folds, prized for its texture.
habitat: Base of coniferous trees, especially pine

name: Cedarwood Waxcap
description: A pale yellow waxcap with a distinctive cedarwood scent.

name: Chanterelle
description: A golden-yellow, funnel-shaped mushroom with a fruity aroma.

name: Charcoal Burner
description: A variable-colored Russula with flexible gills and a mild taste.

name: Chestnut Bolete
description: A small, chestnut-brown bolete with brittle flesh and hollow stem.

name: Chicken of the Woods
description: A bright orange, shelf-like fungus with a texture resembling chicken meat.
habitat: Dead or dying hardwood trees (oak, cherry)

name: Cinnamon Bracket
description: A soft, cinnamon-colored bracket fungus that grows on dead wood. When KOH solution is applied, it turns purple.
habitat: Dead hardwood trees, especially oak and beech

name: Clouded Agaric
description: A large, grayish mushroom with a funnel-shaped cap and crowded gills. Emits a strong, unpleasant odor.

name: Clustered Domecap
description: Grows in dense clusters with grayish-brown caps and white gills. Has a mild, pleasant taste.

name: Common Bonnet
description: A small, bell-shaped mushroom with a striated cap. Often grows in clusters on decaying wood.

name: Common Inkcap
description: A gray mushroom that deliquesces (turns into black ink) as it matures. Causes poisoning if consumed with alcohol.
warning: Contains coprine which causes sickness when combined with alcohol

name: Common Morel
description: Highly prized mushroom with honeycomb-like pits on its cap. Must be cooked before eating.

name: Common Puffball
description: Round, white mushroom that releases spores through a hole when mature. Edible only when the interior is pure white.

name: Common Rustgill
description: Orange-brown mushroom with rusty orange spores. Has a very bitter taste.

name: Crimped Gill
description: A small, fan-shaped fungus with crimped gills and a leathery texture.

name: Crimson Waxcap
description: Striking bright red mushroom with a waxy cap and gills. Color fades with age.

name: Cucumber Cap
description: Small brown mushroom with a distinctive cucumber-like odor.

name: Curry Milkcap
description: Small brown mushroom that exudes white latex and smells strongly of curry or maple syrup.

name: Deadly Fibrecap
description: White to pinkish mushroom with fibrous cap. Contains deadly muscarine toxin.

name: Deadly Webcap
description: Reddish-brown mushroom with a web-like veil. Causes kidney failure.
effects: Delayed kidney failure (symptoms appear 2-14 days after ingestion)

name: Deathcap
description: One of the most toxic mushrooms worldwide. Greenish-yellow cap with white gills and a sac-like volva at the base.
warning: Responsible for 90% of fatal mushroom poisonings

name: Deer Shield
description: A common woodland mushroom with a brown, radially streaked cap and free pinkish gills.

name: Destroying Angel
description: Pure white mushroom with a sac-like volva at the base. One of the most toxic mushrooms known.

name: Devil's Bolete
description: Large bolete with a pale cap, red pores, and a bulbous red stem. Turns blue when bruised.

name: Dog Stinkhorn
description: Phallic-shaped fungus with a foul-smelling, slimy spore mass at the tip that attracts insects.

name: Dryad's Saddle
description: Large, scaly bracket fungus with a pattern resembling a pheasant's feathers. Has a cucumber-like aroma.

name: Dusky Puffball
description: Small puffball that starts white but turns dark brown as it matures.

name: Dyer's Mazegill
description: Large, bracket-like polypore that produces yellow and green dyes. Causes root rot in trees.

name: Earthballs
description: Round, potato-like fungi with a tough outer skin and dark, powdery interior when mature.

name: Egghead Mottlegill
description: Tall, slender mushroom with a bell-shaped cap that has a distinctive egg-like appearance when young.
habitat: Horse and cow dung, fertilized grasslands

name: Elfin Saddle
description: Black, saddle-shaped mushroom with a deeply ribbed and pitted stem.
warning: Must be cooked thoroughly; some similar species are toxic

name: Fairy Ring Champignon
description: Small, tan mushroom that grows in circular patterns called fairy rings. Has a sweet, almond-like smell.

name: False Chanterelle
description: Orange mushroom resembling a true chanterelle but with true gills rather than ridges.

name: False Deathcap
edibility: Poisonous (but less toxic than true deathcap)
description: Yellow or white mushroom with a sac-like volva, resembling the deadly deathcap.

name: False Morel
description: Brain-like or saddle-shaped mushroom that resembles true morels. Contains gyromitrin toxin.

name: False Saffron Milkcap
description: Orange mushroom that exudes carrot-colored milk. Less desirable than true saffron milkcap.

name: Fenugreek Milkcap
description: Pale brown mushroom with a strong fenugreek or curry-like odor when dried.

name: Field Blewit
description: Large, lilac-tinged mushroom with a smooth cap and crowded gills. Smells floral.

name: Field Mushroom
description: Classic white mushroom with pink gills that turn brown. The wild version of supermarket mushrooms.

name: Fleecy Milkcap
description: Large, white mushroom with a woolly cap surface and very hot-tasting latex.

name: Fly Agaric
description: Iconic red mushroom with white spots. Contains psychoactive compounds.
note: Used traditionally in some cultures for its psychoactive properties

name: Fool's Funnel
description: Small white funnel-shaped mushroom often growing in fairy rings. Extremely toxic and easily confused with edible species.

name: Fragrant Funnel
description: Pale buff-colored mushroom with a strong aniseed odor and funnel-shaped cap.

name: Freckled Dapperling
description: Brown mushroom covered with distinctive dark scales or freckles on its cap.

name: Frosted Chanterelle
description: Small yellow chanterelle with a frosted or powdery appearance on its cap.

name: Funeral Bell
description: Small brown mushroom containing the same deadly amatoxins as the death cap.

name: Geranium Brittlegill
description: Yellowish mushroom with a strong geranium-like odor and very hot taste.

name: Giant Funnel
description: Massive white funnel-shaped mushroom that can grow up to 40cm across.

name: Giant Puffball
description: Enormous spherical mushroom that can reach football size. Must be pure white inside to eat.
note: One of the largest mushroom species

name: Glistening Inkcap
description: Small mushroom with a bell-shaped, grooved cap covered in glistening mica-like particles when young.

name: Golden Bootleg
description: Attractive golden-yellow mushroom with a powdery cap and ring on the stem.

name: Golden Scalycap
description: Yellow-orange mushroom with distinctive golden scales on the cap.
habitat: Clusters on living or dead trees

name: Golden Waxcap
description: Bright yellow, waxy mushroom that maintains its color well into maturity.

name: Greencracked Brittlegill
description: Unique mushroom with a green cap that cracks into patches revealing white flesh underneath.

name: Grey Knight
description: Small grey mushroom with a fibrous cap and white gills. Some similar species are toxic.
warning: Can be confused with poisonous relatives

name: Grey Spotted Amanita
description: Grey-capped Amanita with whitish warts and a swollen base. Causes gastrointestinal upset.

name: Grisettes
description: Grey mushroom with a striated cap margin and sack-like volva but no ring.
warning: Must be distinguished from deadly Amanitas

name: Hairy Curtain Crust
description: Thin, leathery bracket fungus with a hairy upper surface and orange-brown underside.

name: Heath Waxcap
description: Small, bright red-orange waxcap that fades with age.

name: Hedgehog Fungus
description: Pale orange mushroom with spines instead of gills under the cap. Has a pleasant nutty flavor.

name: Hen of the Woods
description: Large, clustered mushroom with multiple grey-brown caps. Also known as Maitake.

name: Honey Fungus
description: Golden-brown mushrooms that grow in clusters with white spores. Known for their bioluminescent mycelium.
habitat: Base of trees and stumps, especially deciduous
warning: Can cause stomach upset in some people; parasitic to trees

name: Hoof Fungus
description: Hard, hoof-shaped bracket fungus with concentric zones. Historically used as tinder.

name: Horn of Plenty
description: Dark gray to black trumpet-shaped mushroom with a delicate flavor. Also called 'black trumpet'.
habitat: Deciduous forests, especially in mossy areas

name: Horse Mushroom
description: Large white mushroom with pink gills turning chocolate brown. Smells of anise when young.
note: Similar to field mushroom but larger

name: Inky Mushroom
description: Gray mushroom that deliquesces into black ink. Causes poisoning if consumed with alcohol.
warning: Contains coprine which reacts with alcohol

name: Jelly Ears
description: Brown, ear-shaped gelatinous fungus that grows on elder trees. Common in Asian cuisine.

name: Jelly Tooth
description: Translucent gelatinous fungus with tooth-like spines underneath.

name: Jubilee Waxcap
description: Bright red waxcap that was discovered during Queen Victoria's Diamond Jubilee celebrations.

name: King Alfred's Cakes
description: Hard, coal-like fungus that grows on ash trees. Named after the burnt cakes legend of King Alfred.

name: Larch Bolete
description: A bolete with a slimy yellow-orange cap and yellow pores, often found near larch trees.
habitat: Symbiotic with larch trees, common in temperate forests
uses: Culinary (requires removal of slimy cap skin)

name: Leccinum albostipitatum
description: A bolete with a scaly stem and a reddish-brown cap, turning black when bruised.
habitat: Found in deciduous forests, often near birch or aspen

name: Liberty Cap
description: A small, conical mushroom with a nipple-like protrusion, known for its psychedelic properties.

name: Lilac Bonnet
description: A small, delicate mushroom with a lilac-colored cap and white gills.
habitat: Deciduous and coniferous forests, often on decaying wood

name: Lilac Fibrecap
description: A small, lilac-colored mushroom with a fibrous cap and brown gills.
habitat: Woodlands, often in mossy or grassy areas

name: Lion's Mane
description: A unique mushroom with long, cascading spines resembling a lion's mane.
habitat: Grows on hardwood trees, particularly beech and oak

name: Lurid Bolete
description: A bolete with a reddish-brown cap and yellow pores that bruise blue.
habitat: Often found near larch trees in Europe and North America

name: Macro Mushroom
description: A tall, parasol-shaped mushroom with a scaly cap and a movable ring on the stem.
habitat: Grassy areas, open woodlands, and fields

name: Magpie Inkcap
description: A distinctive mushroom with a white cap covered in black patches, resembling a magpie.
habitat: Deciduous forests, often near rotting wood

name: Meadow Waxcap
description: A bright orange-yellow mushroom with a waxy texture, often found in grasslands.

name: Medusa Mushroom
description: A rare, red mushroom with finger-like projections, resembling Medusa's hair.

name: Morel
description: A honeycomb-patterned mushroom with a hollow stem and cap.
habitat: Woodlands, burned areas, and disturbed soil

name: Mosaic Puffball
description: A puffball with a mosaic-like outer skin, releasing spores when mature.

name: Oak Bolete
description: A bolete with a brown, reticulated stem and a velvety cap.
habitat: Symbiotic with oak trees in Europe

name: Oak Mazegill
description: A bracket fungus with maze-like gills, growing on oak wood.

name: Oak Polypore
description: A large, hoof-shaped polypore that grows exclusively on oak trees.

name: Ochre Brittlegill
description: A brittle mushroom with an ochre-yellow cap and white gills.

name: Old Man of the Woods
description: A shaggy, black-and-white bolete with a scaly cap.

name: Orange Birch Bolete
description: A bolete with an orange cap and a scaly stem that turns black when cut.

name: Orange Bolete
description: A bolete with a bright orange cap and a white stem covered in dark scales.
habitat: Found near aspen and poplar trees

name: Orange Grisette
description: An orange-capped Amanita with a sack-like volva at the base.
habitat: Deciduous forests, often near birch or beech

name: Orange Peel Fungus
description: A bright orange, cup-shaped fungus resembling discarded orange peels.
habitat: Disturbed soil, paths, and grassy areas

name: Oyster Mushroom
description: A fan-shaped, shelf-like mushroom with a smooth, grayish cap and white gills.

name: Pale Oyster
description: A lighter-colored variant of the oyster mushroom with a delicate flavor.

name: Panthercap
description: A brownish cap with white warts, resembling the deadly Death Cap.

name: Parasol
description: A tall mushroom with a scaly cap and a snake-like patterned stem.

name: Parrot Waxcap
description: A small, brightly colored mushroom with a slimy green or yellow cap.

name: Pavement Mushroom
description: A robust mushroom often found pushing through pavement cracks.

name: Penny Bun
description: A thick, brown-capped bolete with a spongy pore surface.

name: Peppery Bolete
description: A small bolete with a reddish-brown cap and a spicy taste.

name: Pestle Puffball
description: A pear-shaped puffball with a rough outer skin.

name: Pine Bolete
description: A yellow-capped bolete with a sticky surface, often found near pines.

name: Pink Waxcap
description: A striking pink mushroom with a waxy texture.

name: Plums and Custard
description: A purple-and-yellow mushroom with a fruity smell.

name: Poison Pie
description: A small brown mushroom with a radish-like odor.

name: Poplar Bell
description: A gray-brown mushroom with free gills, often found on decaying wood.

name: Poplar Fieldcap
description: A small, brown mushroom that grows in clusters near poplars.

name: Porcelain Fungus
description: A translucent white mushroom with a slimy cap, growing on beech trees.

name: Powdery Brittlegill
description: A blue-gray capped mushroom with a powdery surface.

name: Purple Brittlegill
description: A dark purple mushroom with brittle white gills.

name: Red-Belted Bracket
description: A woody bracket fungus with red and cream bands.

name: Red Cracking Bolete
description: A reddish-brown bolete with a cracked cap surface.

name: Root Rot
description: A fungus that causes root rot in conifer trees.

name: Rooting Bolete
description: A large, pale bolete with a deeply rooting stem.

name: Rooting Shank
description: A tall, slender mushroom with a deeply rooted stem.

name: Rosy Bonnet
description: A small pink mushroom with a delicate appearance.

name: Ruby Bolete
description: A small, reddish bolete with yellow pores.

name: Saffron Milkcap
description: An orange mushroom that exudes a carrot-colored latex when cut.

name: Scaly Wood Mushroom
description: A white mushroom with brown scales and a pleasant almond scent.

name: Scarlet Caterpillarclub
description: A bright orange fungus that parasitizes insect larvae.
habitat: Forest soils where insects are present

name: Scarlet Elf Cup
description: A bright red, cup-shaped fungus growing on decaying wood.

name: Scarlet Waxcap
description: A small, bright red mushroom with a waxy texture, often found in unfertilized grasslands.

name: Scarletina Bolete
edibility: Edible (when cooked, but can cause stomach upset in some)
description: A striking bolete with a dark red stem and yellow pores that bruise blue.

name: Semifree Morel
description: A morel with a honeycombed cap that is only partially attached to the stem.
habitat: Woodlands, especially near ash and elm trees

name: Sepia Bolete
description: A brownish bolete with a velvety cap and yellow pores.

name: Shaggy Bracket
description: A large, hairy bracket fungus that grows on living or dead hardwood trees.
habitat: Deciduous forests, especially on ash and oak

name: Shaggy Inkcap
description: A tall, white mushroom with shaggy scales that dissolves into black ink as it matures.

name: Shaggy Parasol
edibility: Edible (but can cause stomach upset in some)
description: A large mushroom with a scaly cap and a double-edged ring on the stem.

name: Shaggy Scalycap
edibility: Edible (with caution, can cause stomach upset)
description: A yellowish mushroom with shaggy scales, growing in clusters on wood.

name: Sheathed Woodtuft
edibility: Edible (but easily confused with deadly Galerina)
description: A small, brown mushroom with a ring on the stem, growing in clusters on wood.

name: Silky Rosegill
description: A beautiful white mushroom with a silky cap and pink gills, growing on wood.

name: Silverleaf Fungus
description: A purple-silvery crust fungus that causes silver leaf disease in trees.

name: Slender Parasol
description: A tall, slender mushroom with a scaly cap and a snake-like patterned stem.

name: Slimy Waxcap
description: A small, yellow-orange mushroom with a sticky, slimy cap.

name: Slippery Jack
description: A brown-capped bolete with a slimy surface and yellow pores.

name: Smoky Bracket
description: A grayish bracket fungus with a smoky appearance, growing on dead wood.

name: Snakeskin Grisette
edibility: Edible (but easily confused with deadly Amanitas)
description: A brownish Amanita with a snakeskin-like pattern on the stem.

name: Snowy Waxcap
description: A pure white, waxy mushroom found in old grasslands.

name: Spectacular Rustgill
description: A large, orange mushroom with rusty brown spores.

name: Splendid Waxcap
description: A bright red-orange mushroom with a waxy texture.

name: Splitgill
edibility: Edible (but tough, more common in Asian cuisine)
description: A small, fan-shaped mushroom with gills that split lengthwise.

name: Spotted Toughshank
description: A white mushroom with reddish spots and a tough stem.

name: Spring Fieldcap
description: A small, brown mushroom that appears in spring, often in grassy areas.

name: St. George's Mushroom
description: A thick, white mushroom with a mealy odor, fruiting around St. George's Day (April).

name: Stinkhorn
edibility: Edible (when young, but foul-smelling when mature)
description: A phallic-shaped mushroom that emits a strong rotting odor to attract flies.

name: Stinking Dapperling
description: A small, white mushroom with a scaly cap and a foul odor.

name: Stubble Rosegill
description: A pale mushroom with pink gills and a volva at the base.

name: Stump Puffball
description: A small, pear-shaped puffball that grows in clusters on decaying wood.

name: Suede Bolete
description: A brownish bolete with a velvety cap and yellow pores.

name: Sulphur Tuft
description: A bright yellow-green mushroom that grows in dense clusters on wood.

name: Summer Bolete
description: A choice edible bolete with a brown, net-like pattern on its stem. Appears earlier in the season than other boletes.

name: Tawny Funnel
description: Orange-brown funnel-shaped mushroom with a depressed center and decurrent gills.

name: Tawny Grisette
description: Orange-brown mushroom with striated cap margins and a sack-like volva. No ring present.
warning: Must be distinguished from poisonous Amanitas

name: Terracotta Hedgehog
description: Smaller relative of the hedgehog fungus with terracotta-colored caps and spines underneath.

name: The Blusher
description: Pinkish-brown Amanita that bruises red when damaged. Must be thoroughly cooked to destroy toxins.

name: The Deceiver
description: Variable colored mushroom that 'deceives' foragers with its changing appearance.

name: The Goblet
description: Deeply funnel-shaped mushroom resembling a wine goblet, with dark brown coloration.

name: The Miller
description: White, mealy-scented mushroom with decurrent gills that turn pink at maturity.

name: The Prince
description: Large, aromatic mushroom with scaly brown cap and almond scent. Considered a choice edible.

name: The Sickener
description: Bright red mushroom with pure white gills and extremely acrid taste.

name: Thimble Morel
description: Bell-shaped morel relative with a thimble-like cap hanging free from the stem.
warning: Must be cooked thoroughly; some report sensitivities

name: Tripe Fungus
description: Rubbery, brain-like fungus resembling tripe meat. Grows in overlapping clusters.

name: Trooping Funnel
description: Large, cream-colored funnel mushroom that often grows in fairy rings.

name: Truffles
description: Highly prized underground fungi with intense aromas. Hunted with trained dogs or pigs.
note: Includes species like black Prigord and white Alba truffles

name: Tuberous Polypore
description: Tough polypore that grows from sclerotia (hard fungal masses) underground.

name: Turkey Tail
description: Colorful, fan-shaped bracket fungus with concentric zones of different colors.

name: Velvet Shank
description: Clustered orange mushrooms with velvety dark stems. Grows in cold weather.

name: Vermillion Waxcap
description: Small, bright red waxcap that fades to orange with age.

name: Warted Amanita
description: Variation of The Blusher with yellow warts and ring. Causes gastrointestinal distress.

name: Weeping Widow
description: Brown mushroom with droplets on its gills that resemble tears.

name: White Dapperling
description: Pure white mushroom with a smooth cap and pinkish gills when mature.
warning: Can be confused with deadly white Amanitas

name: White Domecap
description: A small white mushroom with a convex to flat cap, often growing in clusters.
habitat: Grasslands, wood edges, and disturbed soils

name: White False Death Cap
description: A pale yellow to white mushroom resembling the deadly Death Cap but less dangerous.

name: White Fibrecap
description: A small white mushroom with a conical cap and fibrous texture.

name: White Saddle
description: A distinctive mushroom with a white, saddle-shaped cap and deeply ribbed stem.

name: Winter Chanterelle
description: A small, funnel-shaped mushroom with a brown cap and yellow stem, fruiting in late autumn/winter.

name: Wood Blewit
description: A purple-tinged mushroom with a smooth cap and crowded gills.

name: Wood Mushroom
description: A white to cream-colored mushroom with a pleasant almond scent, similar to the field mushroom.

name: Woodland Inkcap
description: A small, delicate mushroom that deliquesces (turns to ink) as it matures.

name: Woolly Milkcap
description: A pinkish mushroom with woolly edges and white latex that turns yellow.

name: Wrinkled Peach
edibility: Edible (but rare and not highly regarded)
description: A beautiful pinkish mushroom with a wrinkled, net-like cap surface.

name: Yellow False Truffle
description: A subterranean fungus resembling a small, yellow potato.

name: Yellow Foot Waxcap
description: A small yellow mushroom with a waxy texture and slender stem.

name: Yellow Stagshorn
description: A bright yellow, coral-like fungus growing on conifer wood.

name: Yellow Stainer
description: A mushroom resembling the field mushroom but stains yellow when bruised and has a phenolic odor.

name: Yellow Swamp Brittlegill
description: A bright yellow mushroom with brittle gills and a mild taste.
